subhead: The filmmaker explores the extremist drift in the United States today in his new film, loosely adapted from Thomas Pynchon's novel 'Vineland.'

headline: Paris' Mausolée, once a clandestine graffiti residence, now opens its doors to the public
subhead: Lek & Sowat, a duo of graffiti artists who took over an abandoned supermarket beneath Paris' ring road 15 years ago for an experimental project, are sharing the adventure this autumn.

headline: 'In Sudan, it is as if a congenital curse is at work. And the worst is yet to come'
subhead: Straddling the Arab world and Africa, this enduring military dictatorship has seen almost continuous armed conflict since gaining independence in 1956. Its neighbor, the young state of South Sudan, is suffering a similar tragedy, writes Le Monde columnist Alain Frachon.

headline: San Francisco's comeback is fueled by AI giants
subhead: San Francisco's new mayor, Daniel Lurie, boasts about the city's falling crime rate, the return of residents and tourists and its rise as a hub for artificial intelligence, though he admits problems remain.

headline: Relationship sex: Why many women still feel pressure to say yes
subhead: Many women have sex with their partners even when they do not want to, out of reluctance to say no, uncertainty about desire, or fear of offending. Together, these reasons sketch the contours of a gray zone of consent.
